segment.source: Lab 1d: Add a provisioning package to an image
segment.target: Lab 1d: Add a provisioning package to an image

segment.source: Lab 1d: Add a provisioning package to an image
segment.target: Lab 1d: Add a provisioning package to an image

segment.source: This content has been tested on Windows 10 IoT Core Build 10586.
segment.target: This content has been tested on Windows 10 IoT Core Build 10586.

segment.source: Some of these procedures do not yet work on newer preview builds, including Windows 10, version 1607.
segment.target: Some of these procedures do not yet work on newer preview builds, including Windows 10, version 1607.

segment.source: We'll create a provisioning package that contains some sample Wi-Fi settings.
segment.target: We'll create a provisioning package that contains some sample Wi-Fi settings.

segment.source: You can use provisioning package in Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) to add apps, drivers, features, or to modify many common settings, such as IT device management and policy settings.
segment.target: You can use provisioning package in Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) to add apps, drivers, features, or to modify many common settings, such as IT device management and policy settings.

segment.source: Note, to test Wi-Fi, your board will need Wi-Fi support.
segment.target: Note, to test Wi-Fi, your board will need Wi-Fi support.

segment.source: You can use a Wi-Fi adapter/dongle, or use a board like the Raspberry Pi 3 that has Wi-Fi built-in.
segment.target: You can use a Wi-Fi adapter/dongle, or use a board like the Raspberry Pi 3 that has Wi-Fi built-in.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: We'll start with the ProjectA image we created from Lab 1a: Create a basic image, and updated in Lab 1b: Add an app to your image and Lab 1c: Add a file and a registry setting to an image.
segment.target: We'll start with the ProjectA image we created from Lab 1a: Create a basic image, and updated in Lab 1b: Add an app to your image and Lab 1c: Add a file and a registry setting to an image.

segment.source: Create your provisioning package in Windows ICD
segment.target: Create your provisioning package in Windows ICD

segment.source: Start Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.
segment.target: Start Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer.

segment.source: Click File New project.
segment.target: Click File New project.

segment.source: For this example, use the name "ProductAprov" for the product name, accept the defaults, and click Next.
segment.target: For this example, use the name "ProductAprov" for the product name, accept the defaults, and click Next.

segment.source: Select Provisioning package Windows 10 IoT Core.
segment.target: Select Provisioning package Windows 10 IoT Core.

segment.source: At the Import a provisioning package (optional) page, click Finish.
segment.target: At the Import a provisioning package (optional) page, click Finish.

segment.source: Add a sample setting:
segment.target: Add a sample setting:

segment.source: Expand Runtime settings Connectivity Profiles WLAN WLANSetting SSID.
segment.target: Expand Runtime settings Connectivity Profiles WLAN WLANSetting SSID.

segment.source: Type in the name of a Wi-Fi network name, for example, ContosoWiFi, and click Add.
segment.target: Type in the name of a Wi-Fi network name, for example, ContosoWiFi, and click Add.

segment.source: Expand the SSID > WLANXmlSettings > SecurityType and choose a setting such as Open.
segment.target: Expand the SSID > WLANXmlSettings > SecurityType and choose a setting such as Open.

segment.source: Expand the SSID > WLANXmlSettings > AutoConnect and choose a setting such as TRUE.
segment.target: Expand the SSID > WLANXmlSettings > AutoConnect and choose a setting such as TRUE.

segment.source: Optional: to add more than one WLAN network, go back to WLANSetting, and repeat the process.
segment.target: Optional: to add more than one WLAN network, go back to WLANSetting, and repeat the process.

segment.source: Optional: add other apps, drivers, and settings through the UI.
segment.target: Optional: add other apps, drivers, and settings through the UI.

segment.source: To learn more, see Configure customizations using Windows ICD.
segment.target: To learn more, see Configure customizations using Windows ICD.

segment.source: Export the provisioning package.
segment.target: Export the provisioning package.

segment.source: For example, click Export Provisioning Package Next Next Build.
segment.target: For example, click Export Provisioning Package Next Next Build.

segment.source: (To learn more, see Export a provisioning package.
segment.target: (To learn more, see Export a provisioning package.

segment.source: At the All done!
segment.target: At the All done!

segment.source: page, click the link to the Output location.
segment.target: page, click the link to the Output location.

segment.source: Create a folder for the provisioning package in your test product
segment.target: Create a folder for the provisioning package in your test product

segment.source: In File Explorer, create a new folder, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitProductsProductAprov.
segment.target: In File Explorer, create a new folder, C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitProductsProductAprov.

segment.source: This folder is structure is used by the script: Provisioning.Auto.pkg.xml file in Provisioning.Auto folder.
segment.target: This folder is structure is used by the script: Provisioning.Auto.pkg.xml file in Provisioning.Auto folder.

segment.source: No changes are required.
segment.target: No changes are required.

segment.source: Copy the .ppkg, .cat, and customizations.xml files into this folder.
segment.target: Copy the .ppkg, .cat, and customizations.xml files into this folder.

segment.source: If necessary, rename the files to (your project name)prov.cat and (your project name)prov.ppkg, for example, ProductAprov.cat and ProductAprov.ppkg.
segment.target: If necessary, rename the files to (your project name)prov.cat and (your project name)prov.ppkg, for example, ProductAprov.cat and ProductAprov.ppkg.

segment.source: Optional: update customizations.xml with any desired changes.
segment.target: Optional: update customizations.xml with any desired changes.

segment.source: See Windows provisioning answer file for more info.
segment.target: See Windows provisioning answer file for more info.

segment.source: Check the auto-provisioning scripts to make sure they'll include your new provisioning package (optional)
segment.target: Check the auto-provisioning scripts to make sure they'll include your new provisioning package (optional)

segment.source: Review the package definition file: Provisioning.Auto.pkg.xml: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitCommonPackagesProvisioning.AutoProvisioning.Auto.pkg.xml.
segment.target: Review the package definition file: Provisioning.Auto.pkg.xml: C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitCommonPackagesProvisioning.AutoProvisioning.Auto.pkg.xml.

segment.source: No changes should required.
segment.target: No changes should required.

segment.source: Make sure that the package definition file is referenced in the feature manifest.
segment.target: Make sure that the package definition file is referenced in the feature manifest.

segment.source: For example, check C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitCommonPackagesOEMCommonFM.xml:
segment.target: For example, check C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitCommonPackagesOEMCommonFM.xml:

segment.source: Add the FeatureID to your test configuration file C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-ProductsProductATestOEMInput.xml:
segment.target: Add the FeatureID to your test configuration file C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitSource-ProductsProductATestOEMInput.xml:

segment.source: Build and test the image
segment.target: Build and test the image

segment.source: Build the image
segment.target: Build the image

segment.source: From the IoT Core Shell, create the image:
segment.target: From the IoT Core Shell, create the image:

segment.source: This creates the product binaries at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATestFlash.FFU.
segment.target: This creates the product binaries at C:IoT-ADK-AddonKitBuildarchProductATestFlash.FFU.

segment.source: Start Windows IoT Core DashboardSetup a new deviceCustom, and browse to your image.
segment.target: Start Windows IoT Core DashboardSetup a new deviceCustom, and browse to your image.

segment.source: Put the Micro SD card in the device, select it, accept the license terms, and click Install.
segment.target: Put the Micro SD card in the device, select it, accept the license terms, and click Install.

segment.source: This replaces the previous image with our new image.
segment.target: This replaces the previous image with our new image.

segment.source: Put the card into the IoT device and start it up.
segment.target: Put the card into the IoT device and start it up.

segment.source: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see your app.
segment.target: After a short while, the device should start automatically, and you should see your app.

segment.source: Check to see if your provisioning settings were applied
segment.target: Check to see if your provisioning settings were applied

segment.source: Connect a network cable.
segment.target: Connect a network cable.

segment.source: On your technician PC, open Internet Explorer, and type in the address with an http:// prefix and :8080 suffix:
segment.target: On your technician PC, open Internet Explorer, and type in the address with an http:// prefix and :8080 suffix:

segment.source: This opens the Windows Device Portal.
segment.target: This opens the Windows Device Portal.

segment.source: From here, you can upload app packages, see what apps are installed, and switch between them.
segment.target: From here, you can upload app packages, see what apps are installed, and switch between them.

segment.source: Use the default username (Administrator) and password (p@ssw0rd) to log on.
segment.target: Use the default username (Administrator) and password (p@ssw0rd) to log on.

segment.source: Click Networking.
segment.target: Click Networking.

segment.source: Check the Profiles drop-down, you should see the Wi-Fi profile you created.
segment.target: Check the Profiles drop-down, you should see the Wi-Fi profile you created.

segment.source: If the device is able to automatically connect to the WiFi network, then under Available Networks, you should see a checkmark next to the network you configured.
segment.target: If the device is able to automatically connect to the WiFi network, then under Available Networks, you should see a checkmark next to the network you configured.

segment.source: If your network requires steps such as accepting license terms, the device may not auto-connect.
segment.target: If your network requires steps such as accepting license terms, the device may not auto-connect.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image
segment.target: Lab 1e: Add a driver to an image
